content: I noticed that if I want to define a polynomial in ℚ[X], I have to mark the definition as noncomputable. Why is this the case? I would expect this for e.g reals but not for rationals. In particular I would like to evaluate such a polynomial at a specific point in ℚ and actually compute the result, is there an easy way to do this?
Polynomials are not computable in that sense in mathlib

Yaël Dillies said:

See eg https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Way.20to.20recover.20computability.3F

Thanks. So the easiest way is to e.g define a function converting to lists of rationals, and manually write an evaluation function for that type?
It depends on what kind of polynomials you care about, but this is one solution yes.
Timothy Z has marked this topic as resolved.
